awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Linear Impactor System to Study Injury Mechanisms and Severity at University of Michigan, Dearborn
awd_abstract_narration:
Severe impacts on the human body, particularly to the head and chest, caused by sports or motor vehicle accidents can be fatal. Understanding the injury mechanisms and the severity of injury caused by such events is, therefore, of great importance. Such information will help engineers to better design protective materials and equipment. Obviously, this type of information cannot be gathered during actual events and therefore artificial models are utilized. To simulate impacts, an artificial model of the head and eyes are subjected to forces in a controlled and measurable manner in laboratory settings. Valuable information is therefore gained about injury mechanisms and the severity of injury caused by bodily collisions. This award provides funding to obtain a Linear Impactor System to study injury mechanisms and severity. The equipment will be used to study the response of an artificial body to various impacts. It will also help in designing protective materials and devices and formulating revised safety measures. Partnerships between engineering, social sciences, medicine, and external collaborators will lead to high-impact and novel research. Acquisition of this system will enhance the education of both undergraduate and graduate students. It will be also used in outreach activities to attract high school and middle school students to STEM fields.

This instrumentation will be used on various research programs spanning a wide breadth. These programs include: (i) the relationship between neck strength and head acceleration (ii) biomechanics of injuries due to intimate partner violence (iii) examination of sensors to monitor head acceleration (iv) the efficacy and mechanical behavior of personal protective equipment such as helmets, soft headgear and face masks (v) characterization of the mechanobiological response of the eye to impact (vi) and the understanding of mechanical changes in the heart during an impact to the thorax. The knowledge generated will help to develop a more accurate forensic analysis of injury and to increase understanding of the fundamental behavior of hard and soft tissue injury.  Researchers also will study the relation of injury to loading rate and body acceleration, and the optimum methods to reduce the likelihood of injury for incidents related to sports, falls, violence and transportation crash.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When the human body is subjected to impacts due to violence, sports, falls or motor vehicle accidents, particularly to the head or chest, it is possible to be severely injured or even die. The objective of this MRI proposal was to acquire a system to study injury mechanisms and the severity of injury caused by medium velocity bodily collisions. This device has allowed us to apply loads in a controlled, measurable manner to simulate impacts that cause injury. This project supported both research and education in engineering at the University of Michigan – Dearborn. The instrumentation purchased improved infrastructure on campus by significantly enhancing the ability to study human soft and hard tissue injury mechanisms and protective materials. It has been used by four faculty at two institutions and approximately 36 students for either research or educational purposes. Three manuscripts have been published in peer reviewed journals, two using the Facial Ocular CountermeasUre for Safety (FOCUS) headform to examine injury risk of less lethal impact munitions and one study examining the efficacy of women’s lacrosse headgear to reduce various concussion metrics. One significant finding was that two commercially available women’s lacrosse headgear were able to significantly reduce various head injury metrics such as peak linear acceleration, head injury criteria (HIC), peak rotational acceleration and velocity and Brain Injury Criteria (BRIC) at several impact speeds, but the reductions were more subtle for the rotational velocity-based metrics (PRV and BrIC) than they were for the other metrics. Part of the instrumentation, the FOCUS headform, was used to assess the risk of injury (ROI) (fracture) from less lethal impact munition (LLIM) impacts to facial bones. A significant finding was that risk of injury was from ~ 30% up to 95% to the frontal bone and ~ 30% up to 99% for the maxilla. In general, 12-gauge LLIMs had a lower ROI than the larger caliber LLIMs and the rubber projectiles had a lower ROI than the bean bag style projectiles. In addition to published manuscripts, students or faculty have presented four abstracts at national conferences on topics related to less lethal munitions, lacrosse headgear, and head injuries caused by falls in the elderly.

 

This instrumentation has been successfully used for educational purposes at the University of Michigan - Dearborn. One graduate student used this equipment to collect data for his master’s thesis. Two undergraduate students have used this equipment for directed study research, and one senior design team tested their final design of an end cap modeled after the human fist that can be used to study intimate partner violence. In addition, a laboratory was developed for one course (Advanced Biomechanics BENG470/570). Over two semesters, the class had an enrollment of 30 students total. The students in the course were all trained to use the instrumentation and successfully collected and analyzed data related to head protection. The equipment purchased through this award will continue to be used by faculty and students for research, educational, and outreach purposes.
